intro: Chaerophyllum hirsutum var. rubriflorum, commonly known as the red-flowered hogweed, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its compound leaves and showy, umbellate flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, shady environments such as woodlands and stream banks. Its flowers range in color from white to deep red, depending on the variety, and it produces small, dry fruits known as schizocarps. Due to its attractive appearance, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens, though it can be invasive in certain regions.
